column8: An improvisational comedy theatre troupe, Second City's talented cast creates original sketches for adult audiences.'
Kingston Mines is one of Chicago's oldest and largest blues joints where concerts and dancing don't stop until the early morning.'
The Riviera Theatre is a concert venue popular for both local and national acts'
The Aragon Ballroom is a concert venue & event paced designed to replicate an ornate Spanish palace courtyard'
Deemed one of Chicago‰Ûªs best bakeries, this Lincoln Park shop offers a rotating menu of French pastries, bread, sandwiches and salads. A perfect spot to grab breakfast or lunch.'
With two locations in Wicker Park and Logan Square, this bar has nearly 40 arcade games, two dozen rotating craft beers and over 50 whiskeys. The Logan Square spot also has pool tables.'
A trip to Chicago‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏLittle India‰Ûù will be well worth it. Udupi is one of the many gems on Devon Avenue that specializes in southern Indian dishes. Vegetarian dishes only.'
A trendy, upscale restaurant by reality TV stars Bill & Giuliana Rancic. The River North spot, which offers modern Italian fare, is a place to see and be seen.'
An upscale diner in Chicago‰Ûªs West Loop offering dishes from omelettes to foie gras. Its cheeseburger, however, is known as one of the best in the city.'

If you want to see the Bulls or the Blackhawks, you‰Ûªll need to make a trip to this sprawling Near West Side sports arena. When it‰Ûªs not hosting hockey or basketball, it‰Ûªs the venue of choice for gigantic touring acts like BeyoncÌ© and Lady Gaga.'

Located on Chicago's south side, U.S. Cellular Field is home to the 2005 World Series Champions. More modern and spacious than Wrigley, it also offers creative stadium fare like bacon on a stick and chicken and waffle sandwiches.'

During football season, Soldier Field is the perfect place to tailgate and catch a game. Opened in 1924, it is the oldest NFL stadium. During the offseason, it serves as one of Chicago‰Ûªs largest concert venues.'

Located on Chicago‰Ûªs northside, Wrigley Field is the second-oldest major league ballpark and has been the home to the Cub‰Ûªs for 99 seasons. The surrounding neighborhood known as ‰ÛÏWrigleyville‰Ûù offers sports fans a variety of restaurants and bars.'
Chicago Theatre is a landmark performing arts venue for stage plays, magic shows, comedy, speeches, and popular music concerts. '

column1: Broadway Playhouse at Water Tower Place

column8: This art museum is the second-largest art museum in the United States most famous for its collections of Impressionist, Post-Impressionist, and American paintings.'

Described as ‰ÛÏlandscape art under glass‰Ûù when it opened in 1908, the Garfield Park Conservatory is one of the largest of its kind in the nation. Inside, visitors will find 120,000 plants spread across 1.6 acres. A popular rain-or-shine destination for nature lovers, the conservatory hosts seasonal flower shows as well as occasional concerts and events.'

Take a trip to Lincoln Park, where visitors can learn about the natural world at the Peggy Notebaert Nature Museum. Outside, a series of nature trails take explorers past a lagoon and a prairie garden, while indoor attractions include interactive ecosystems and the 2,700-square-foot Judy Istock Butterfly Haven.'
The Field Museum is a premier natural history museum'
This museum is the largest science museum in the Western Hemisphere. It is a Chicago landmark.'
This first Mexican cultural center in the Midwest and the largest in the nation featuring Mexican, Latino, and Chicano art and culture. '
This museum explores both Chicago and American history houses Chicago's most important collection of programs, publications, and online resources.'

Steps away from the Mag Mile, the museum is one of Chicago‰Ûªs historic treasures. Once the home of 19th-century banker, Samuel Mayo Nickerson, the galleries transports visitors back to Chicago‰Ûªs Gilded Age.'

column1: Dusable Museum of African American History
column8: The first and oldest museum dedicated to the study and conservation of African American history, culture, and art.'
Chicago‰Ûªs Magnificent Mile is the perfect place for a shopping experience. It boosts a variety of retail shops, designer boutiques, department stores and dining options.'
The Shops at Roosevelt Collection delivers upscale retail and sophisticated urban living in the heart of Chicago's South Loop.'
Better known as ‰ÛÏThe Bean‰Ûù because of its shape, Cloud Gate is one of Chicago‰Ûªs most'

This tourist hot spot features shops, eateries, an IMAX cinema and sightseeing boat tours. The 150-foot-high Ferris wheel is one its most popular attractions, but you can also find the Chicago Children's Museum and a rotating roster of live entertainment on the Family Pavilion Stage.'
See some 1,200 animals, from apes to zebras, at the oldest and one of only a few free zoos left in the country. It is small, only 35 acres, but is one of Chicago‰Ûªs most iconic sites.'

Millennium Park contains a selection of Chicago‰Ûªs most iconic sights, ranging from the popular Cloud Gate to the towering Crown Fountain. When the weather is warm, you can see a free concert at the Frank Gehry‰ÛÒdesigned Pritzker Pavilion or have a picnic in the heart of the city.'

Take in some amazing views of Lake Michigan along the 18-mile Lakefront Trail. Run, bike or walk along the path, which connects attractions like the Museum Campus, Belmont Harbor, McCormick Place and most of the city‰Ûªs beaches.'

This video sculpture, which features a rotating display of local faces, is located next to many of Chicago‰Ûªs top attractions in Millennium Park. In the warmer months, the fountain allows visitors a chance to cool off.'

column1: Howl at the Moon Piano Bar

column8: One hundred and three floors above the streets, visitors can see as far as 50 miles in all directions from the top of the iconic skyscraper. If you‰Ûªre feeling brave, step out onto the Ledge‰ÛÓa glass cube suspended from the side of the building that will make you feel like you‰Ûªre walking on air.'

Formerly known as the John Hancock Observatory, 360 Chicago offers visitors with a view of up to 55 miles out and four states from 1,000 feet up on the 94th floor. The Tilt attraction, which allows visitors to step onto an enclosed platform that extends from the building at a 30 degree angle offers a stomach-dropping view of the street below.'
With breathtaking architecture and an abundance of cultural attractions, Chinatown is one of Chicago's most exciting neighborhoods to explore. '
